Body:
BC-HOTDOGS-1600(2Takes)-TEX 
FRANK TALK, JUST IN TIME FOR YOUR LABOR DAY COOKOUT

 (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) 
By BEVERLY BUNDY 
c.1998 Fort Worth Star-Telegram 

   Labor Day marks the end of high season for hot dogs. Between May
and the unofficial end of summer, Americans chomp down on 880
million franks. And the eating goes on, no matter the season;
yearly, Americans enjoy a total of 2 billion hot dogs. That's about
60 dogs for every man, woman and child. Here are some hotdog
factoids:

   _

   COLONEL MUSTARD

   Most Americans top their dogs with mustard (60 percent). The
youngest among us prefer ketchup.

   _

   CHUBBY DOGS

   Most Americans choose the full-fat version; only 11 percent of
hot dogs sold in supermarkets are low-fat or nonfat.

   _

   HOW TO DRESS A DOG

   Apply condiments in this order:

   1. Wet ones first, such as mustard or chili.

   2. Then chunky stuff, such as relish, onion, sauerkraut and
cheese.

   3. Finally, if you're from Chicago, sprinkle on the celery salt.

   _

   DOG DO'S AND DON'TS

   DO

   Serve sesame seed, poppy seed and plain buns. Sun-dried tomato
buns or basil buns are considered gauche with franks.

   Treat hot dogs on buns as finger food. Flatware should not touch
hot dogs on buns.

   Lick off andy ketchup/mustard/chili/onions remaining on fingers
after eating.

   DON'T

   Take more than five bites to finish eating your hot dog. For a
foot-long dog, seven bites are acceptable.

   Put toppings between the dog and the bun. Always layer
condiments on top of the frankfurter.

   Use ketchup if you're more than 18 years old.

   _ National Hot Dog & Sausage Council

   _

   ``In place of the single hot dog of today, there should be a
variety as great as that which has come to prevail among
sandwiches. There should be hot dogs for all appetites, all tastes,
all occasions. They should come in rolls of every imaginable kind
and be accompanied by every sort of relish, from Worcestershire
sauce to chutney. The hot dog should be elevated to the level of an
art form.''

   _ H.L. Mencken, 1929

   _

   THE FAMOUS AND THE FRANKFURTER

   Babe Ruth once downed 12 hot dogs and eight bottles of soda
between a doubleheader. He was rushed to the hospital with a severe
case of indigestion.

   Marlene Dietrich said hot dogs and champagne made up one of her
favorite meals.

   In 1995, three Seattle Seahawks were fined $1,000 each for
eating hot dogs on the sideline during a preseason game.

   _

   A TASTE TEST

   Our informal panel of four testers tried a dozen supermarket hot
dogs. All were grilled indoors for the same amount of time and were
served plain, sans bread or condiments. The winners are, not
surprisingly, the premium-brand beef franks:

   1. Usinger's Beef Frankfurters (certified Angus beef)

   $3.89

   Calories per dog 180

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   15 grams 75 380 mg

   Comments: Nice, crispy outside. Sausagelike interior.

   2. Nathan's Beef Franks

   $2.99

   Calories per dog 160

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   15 grams 84 490 mg

   Comments: This tastes very familiar. Slightly smoky flavor.
3. Boar's Head Brand Beef Franks

   $3.99

   Calories per dog 120

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   11 grams 82.5 350 mg

   Comments: Moist with a nice, chewy interior.
4. Oscar Mayer Jumbo Wieners

   $2.19

   Calories per dog 180

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   17 grams 85 550 mg

   Comments: Quite tasty with a good, firm texture.
5. Ball Park Beef Franks

   $3.19

   Calories per dog 180

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   16 grams 80 670 mg

   Comments: The outside texture is the same as the inside _ a
plus.
6. Decker Jumbo Beef Franks

   $2.50

   Calories per dog 190

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   17 grams 81 560 mg

   Comments: Firm and spongy _ not a good thing.
7. Eckrich Bun-Size Franks (turkey, pork and beef)

   $2.99

   Calories per dog 170

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   14 grams 74 590 mg

   Comments: Not quite doglike enough.
8. Ball Park Franks (beef, pork and turkey)

   $2.19

   Calories per dog 180

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   16 grams 80 660 mg

   Comments: Flabby _ could do with some aerobic conditioning.
9. Louis Rich Original (turkey and chicken)

   $1.19

   Calories per dog 80

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   6 grams 67.6 490 mg

   Comments: Reminiscent of bologna. Again, not a good thing.
10. Healthy Choice Low Fat Beef Franks

   $2.99

   Calories per dog 80

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   2.5 grams 25 400 mg

   Comments: Great color but the inside is mushy.
11. Butterball Fat Free Franks (turkey)

   $2.99

   Calories per dog 40

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   0 0 490 mg

   Comments: Of the ones we tried, this is the worst!
12. Decker Franks (chicken, pork and beef)

   89 cents

   Calories per dog 110

   Fat % calories from fat Sodium

   9 grams 74 510 mg

   Comments: Wait _ no, this is the worst.

   MORE
